newsitem.title: USA: Crude pipeline link between LOOP and Capline open.
newsitem.headline: Crude pipeline link between LOOP and Capline open.

text.p: The LOCAP crude pipeline link between the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port (LOOP) and the Capline pipeline artery reopened on Saturday after being shut for a leak last Thursday, a LOOP official said Tuesday.
"Repairs were completed over the weekend and after a test of the system, we restored normal operations," said a LOOP official.
"There was only a small loss of crude which was confined to the immediate area. We estimate the loss at about five barrels, and we have made a thorough cleanup at the site," the official added.
Despite the loss of some 700,000 barrels of day (bpd) of crude throughput, LOOP officials said lost streams would be replaced over the course of the month.
Other operations at LOOP, including the unloading of tankers and distribution of oil to other pipelines were not affected by the LOCAP shutdown.
The LOOP, located about 20 miles south of Grand Isle, Louisiana, is the only deep-water port in U.S. waters.
Capline is the major crude oil artery feeding the Midwest (Patoka, Illinois terminal) from the Gulf Coast (St. James, Louisiana terminal) with a capacity of 1.1-1.2 million bpd.

Capline equity owners and their respective shares include: Ashland (21.570 pct); Southcap Pipeline Co (20.998 pct); Shell Oil (13.533 pct) operator; British Petroleum (13.238 pct); Amoco (12.208 pct); USX-Marathon (11.062); and Texaco (7.391 pct).
